snippet.title: New White House chief of staff a square-jawed beacon of discipline
snippet.content:
by Ron Nixon and Michael Shear
President Donald Trump frequently referred to John F. Kelly as one of "my generals", the three senior military leaders he recruited for his Cabinet. On Saturday (AEST), Trump decided to see whether Kelly, a retired four-star Marine Corps general, could impose a new sense of discipline on an unruly and chaotic West Wing. Kelly, who became a star in Trump's eyes for overseeing immigration policy as secretary of homeland security, has become the president's second chief of staff. He replaced Reince Priebus, the establishment Republican who never completely meshed with Trump. The square-jawed Kelly, the first general to hold the chief of staff position since Alexander Haig during the Nixon administration, will be an imposing and strait-laced figure in a West Wing filled with constantly warring aides and advisers, most of whom came to Washington with virtually no experience in federal government before Trump's victory last year. "John has also done a spectacular job at Homeland Security," Trump wrote on Twitter, calling Kelly a "great American" and saying he had been a "true star of my Administration".
Kelly's arrival in his new post could signal a new stability at the White House, but only if Trump gives him the authority to crack down on the behaviour of his other aides. As a real estate developer, Trump has operated with a staff that has often seemed out of control.
The selection of Kelly was at the weekend praised by both Republicans and Democrats, who expressed hope that he would bring a swift end to the distracting feuds among the president's staff. "The kind of discipline that he is going to bring is important," Senator Richard Blumenthal, a democrat, said on CNN shortly after the president's announcement. "I hope that we're at a turning point now." Kelly had no previous connection to Trump until he was nominated to join his administration, though he has long nurtured bipartisan support from members of Congress. And he was not always in lock-step with Trump's policies, publicly questioning the need for a full border wall with Mexico and calling Russia a threat to the US as the president signalled a friendlier approach to Moscow. But over the six months of his tenure leading the Department of Homeland Security, Kelly, whom friends describe as unafraid to challenge his superiors, emerged as an important and highly visible surrogate for the president.
He took a hard line against illegal immigration and weighed into the Russia election interference controversy by defending Jared Kushner, Trump's son-in-law and senior adviser, who tried to open back channel communications with the Kremlin. Kelly said it was "no big deal". For Trump, the decision to put Kelly in charge at the White House reflected a deep desire for someone who can project the kind of strength and decisiveness that the president never saw during the six months that Priebus occupied the corner office down the hall from the Oval Office. Priebus rarely exhibited the kind of top-down control over the president's staff that is typical in a White House, where the chief of staff often exerts strict control over the president's time, the administration's agenda and the public message coming from the communications office. Kelly, who ran the military's operations in Central America, South America and the Caribbean, has the kind of experience that Trump respects: a chest full of medals attesting to his valour and accomplishments.
But Kelly is also a veteran of the political wars in Washington, where he has built long-standing relationships with members of Congress in both parties. Yet, as homeland security secretary, Kelly has lashed out at critics. In May, Kelly was criticised after being caught on an open microphone at a Coast Guard Academy graduation suggesting that Trump use a sword "on the press". During a speech at George Washington University in April, Kelly denounced congressional critics of the Department of Homeland Security, saying they should "shut up" and assume the agency is acting appropriately and following the law. "If lawmakers do not like the laws they've passed and we are charged to enforce, then they should have the courage and skill to change the laws," Kelly said. "Otherwise they should shut up and support the men and women on the front lines."
Such tough talk has played well within the Trump administration, but Juliette Kayyem, a former homeland security official in President Barack Obama's administration who initially supported Kelly, wrote on Twitter that he had been a "disappointment" for those who supported him "as a calming force" in the administration. But more than anything, Kelly's willingness to carry out Trump's immigration policies endeared him to the White House. He forcefully backed Trump on the need for a travel ban on visitors from seven Muslim countries. The ban, which was allowed to go into limited effect by the Supreme Court, was later reduced to six countries. Kelly, whose deputy, Elaine Duke, will become acting secretary, has unleashed the full force of his department on illegal immigration. Under Immigration and Customs Enforcement, part of the Department of Homeland Security, there has been a substantial increase in the number of unauthorised immigrants rounded up for deportation, many of whom were excluded because of Obama administration policies. Apprehensions at the border of people illegally crossing it are also down.
Those results have given the Trump administration, which has largely been unable to gain traction on health care and other issues, one of the few areas in which it can claim success. Trump was particularly pleased with the results at the Mexican border. In a speech on Long Island on Friday before announcing the staff shift, the president praised Kelly's work, calling him "one of our great stars".
